Article Title: Vande Bharat sleeper to be launched in January! Ashwini Vaishnaw announces route & fares; check details & features of new train
Article Text:

Vande Bharat Sleeper Train Fares

According to Indian Railways, the fares of Vande Bharat sleeper train will start from Rs 2,300 for a one way fare between Guwahati and Kolkata.

Vande Bharat sleeper AC 3-tier fare: Rs 2,300

Vande Bharat sleeper AC 2-tier fare: Rs 3,000

Vande Bharat sleeper AC 1st fare: Rs 3,600

Vande Bharat Sleeper Train Features

Built for semi-high-speed operations, the Vande Bharat sleeper is designed to run at speeds of up to 160 kmph, while trial runs have been carried out at 180 kmph. Actual service speeds will vary depending on track infrastructure across the rail network.

Inspired by European train design standards, the Vande Bharat sleeper train coaches will feature cushioned berths for added comfort, along with better access to upper berths to make movement easier for railway passengers.

Onboard facilities include soft night-time lighting, public address systems integrated with visual information displays, CCTV cameras, and modular pantry units.

The train will be equipped with advanced bio-vacuum toilets similar to those used in aircraft. Amenities will include toilets designed for persons with disabilities, a baby care area, and shower facilities with hot water in the air-conditioned first-class coach.

Safety enhancements include the indigenous KAVACH anti-collision system. Like the existing chair car variant, the sleeper version will also use regenerative braking to improve energy efficiency.

Coaches will have fully sealed gangways and automated inter-coach doors, helping maintain consistent air quality and stable cabin temperatures.

Each coach will be fitted with personal reading lights, power charging points, foldable snack tables, and interiors finished with GFRP panels. Train doors will operate automatically at designated stations.

A Centralised Coach Monitoring System is in place, along with emergency communication features that allow passengers to directly contact the locomotive pilot when required.

Vande Bharat sleeper train to be launched soon! In a big New year cheer for Indian Railways passengers, railway minister Ashwini Vaishaw has announced that the first Vande Bharat sleeper train will be launched this month. Prime Minister Narendra Modi is expected to flag off the Vande Bharat sleeper train in the second half of January 2026.Vande Bharat sleeper is a fully air-conditioned train set that has been manufactured by Indian Railways for long-distance routes and overnight journeys. According to Ashwini Vaishnaw , two Vande Bharat sleeper train sets are ready and have undergone successful trial runs. The new trains will be operated on 1,200-1,500 kmph routes of the national transporter.The first Vande Bharat sleeper train will run between Guwahati and Kolkata, Ashwini Vaishnaw announced on Thursday. Each Vande Bharat sleeper train has 16 coaches. The composition of the coaches is: 11 AC 3-tier, 4 AC 2-tier, and one AC 1st coach. The train can accommodate 823 passengers. Vaishnaw said that eight more Vande Bharat sleeper trains will be rolled out in the next six months, and the total will go up to 12 by year-end.The new train is scheduled to run between Howrah and Guwahati (Kamakhya). According to Indian Railways, the following districts will be benefitted:Ashwini Vaishnaw recently shared a video on X, formerly known as Twitter, showcasing the train undergoing high-speed trials on the Indian Railways network.During test runs conducted on the Kota‚ÄìNagda route, the Vande Bharat sleeper train achieved its top design speed of 180 kmph. A notable highlight from the trial was a stability demonstration in which glasses filled with water remained perfectly balanced without any water spilling even at over 180 kmph speed.‚ÄúVande Bharat Sleeper tested today by Commissioner ailway Safety. It ran at 180 kmph between Kota Nagda section. And our own water test demonstrated the technological features of this new generation train,‚Äù Ashwini Vaishnaw wrote in his post on X.Designed for overnight and long-haul journeys, the Vande Bharat sleeper train is the sleeping-class counterpart of the Vande Bharat chair car services already operating across the country.At present, two prototype rakes of the Vande Bharat sleeper train have been produced by BEML. Indian Railways is also gearing up for a broader transformation of long-distance travel, with plans to roll out more than 200 such sleeper trains in the coming years, supported by several ongoing manufacturing initiatives.BEML is jointly producing 10 Vande Bharat sleeper train sets in partnership with the Integral Coach Factory. Another batch of 10 sleeper rakes is being built by Kinet, a joint venture involving Indian and Russian entities. In addition, a consortium led by Titagarh Rail Systems along with BHEL has secured an order to manufacture 80 sleeper-class trainsets. Separately, the Integral Coach Factory is also developing its own sleeper configuration of the Vande Bharat train as an internal project.
Article Summary: Vande Bharat sleeper is a fully air-conditioned train set that has been manufactured by Indian Railways for long-distance routes and overnight journeys. The train will be equipped with advanced bio-vacuum toilets similar to those used in aircraft. The new train is scheduled to run between Howrah and Guwahati (Kamakhya) The train can accommodate 823 passengers.

Article Title: In a 1st in world, Army set to deploy ramjet-powered shells for 155mm artillery guns
Article Text:
From Missiles To Torpedoes, DRDO Outlines India‚Äôs Big Defence Push For Near-Term Battlefield Edge

NEW DELHI: The Indian Army is on the cusp of becoming the world‚Äôs first armed force to operationally deploy ramjet-powered artillery shells for its 155 mm guns. The advanced technology, developed in collaboration with the Indian Institute of Technology (IIT) Madras and with support of Army Technology Board (ATB), is now under trial.Ramjet propulsion is not new and has been used in missiles worldwide. However, applying the technology to artillery shells is a revolutionary step.Professors P A Ramakrishna and S Verma from IIT Madras' Department of Aerospace Engineering co-developed a ramjet-powered artillery shell after years of research. The technology, developed under the Atmanirbhar Bharat initiative, is designed to significantly extend the reach of standard tube artillery.Prof Ramakrishna recently explained that a ramjet operates as an air-breathing engine that does not require turbines or compressors. It relies on the shell being launched to speeds of approx Mach 2 using an artillery gun. At this velocity, air entering the engine is naturally compressed, fuel is ignited and thrust is produced, which allows the shell to maintain propulsion and significantly extend its range.‚ÄúBeing an air-breathing engine, ramjet has higher specific impulse (ISP) (> 4000 N s/kg) compared to that of a solid rocket (~2500 N s/kg) and, therefore, provides much higher overall impulse to the shell for the same mass of propellant,‚Äù the IIT-M research paper said.One of the key challenges IIT-M team faced was using ramjet to have high combustion efficiency with restricted secondary combustor length. However, the team managed to overcome this obstacle.The technology promises to extend the range of conventional artillery shells by 30% to 50% while maintaining their destructive power. By integrating ramjet technology into 155 mm shells, the Army obtained the ability to strike deeper targets with greater effectiveness. Developmental trials are currently under way, with successful tests already conducted at the Pokhran field firing ranges. These trials have demonstrated the feasibility of retrofitting ramjet modules onto existing 155 mm shells, meaning the technology can be applied across the Army‚Äôs current inventory without requiring entirely new ammunition designs.Once the ramjet artillery shell technology is ready for induction, it can be used in any of the Army‚Äôs artillery systems, including on the US-imported M777 ultra-light howitzer.
Article Summary: The Indian Army is on the cusp of becoming the world‚Äôs first armed force to operationally deploy ramjet-powered artillery shells for its 155 mm guns. The technology, developed under the Atmanirbhar Bharat initiative, is designed to significantly extend the reach of standard tube artillery.

Article Title: Red Fort blast: Probe unveils how terrorists spoke to Pakistani handlers - What's a 'ghost' SIM card?
Article Text:
Representative image

Massive Car Explosion Near Delhi‚Äôs Red Fort Hours After Faridabad Terror Plot bust, Many Dead

The ‚Äòdual-phone‚Äô playbook

A disturbing trend

How does the government plan to tackle this?

The

white-collar terror module

NEW DELHI: Investigations into the blast near Delhi‚Äôs Red Fort on November 10 last year have revealed how a "white-collar" terror module relied on a sophisticated network of ‚Äúghost‚Äù SIM cards and encrypted messaging apps to stay in touch with Pakistani handlers.The accused, many of them highly educated doctors, used illegally obtained or fraudulently issued SIM cards and multiple mobile devices to evade surveillance.The findings of this probe subsequently became the basis for a sweeping directive issued by the Department of Telecommunications (DoT) on November 28, mandating that app-based communication services such as WhatsApp, Telegram and Signal must remain continuously linked to an active physical SIM card installed in the device.A ‚Äúghost‚Äù SIM card is a mobile connection that is illegally issued or fraudulently activated without being linked to the actual user, security officials said. Such SIMs are typically obtained using forged or misused identity documents, including Aadhaar details of unsuspecting civilians, or through bulk activations that bypass verification norms.Investigators say these numbers allow criminals and terror operatives to communicate and use encrypted messaging applications while remaining largely untraceable, posing a significant challenge to telecom surveillance and law enforcement agencies.Officials said the probe uncovered a tactical "dual-phone" protocol followed by the module.Each accused carried two to three mobile phones. One "clean" handset, registered in their own name, was used for routine personal and professional communication to avoid suspicion. The second, described as a ‚Äúterror phone‚Äù, was used exclusively for encrypted communication with handlers in Pakistan through WhatsApp and Telegram, officials said.The SIM cards used in these secondary devices were issued in the names of unsuspecting civilians whose Aadhaar details had been misused, the officials told news agency PTI. In a parallel development, Jammu and Kashmir Police also uncovered a separate racket in which SIM cards were issued using fake Aadhaar cards.Among those arrested were Muzammil Ganaie and Adeel Rather, while Dr Umar-un-Nabi, another key accused, was killed while driving an explosives-laden vehicle near the Red Fort, officials said. The Pakistani handlers were identified by the codenames ‚ÄòUkasa‚Äô, ‚ÄòFaizan‚Äô and ‚ÄòHashmi‚Äô.Investigators said security agencies noted a disturbing trend in which these compromised SIMs remained active on messaging platforms even when the devices were being operated from Pakistan-occupied Jammu & Kashmir (PoJK) or Pakistan. By exploiting app features that allow continued access without a physical SIM inside the device, handlers were able to remotely guide the module.Officials said the operatives were directed to learn improvised explosive device (IED) assembly through online videos and plan ‚Äúhinterland‚Äù attacks, even though some of the recruits initially wanted to join conflict zones in Syria or Afghanistan.To plug these vulnerabilities, the Centre invoked the Telecommunications Act, 2023, along with the Telecom Cyber Security Rules, to ‚Äúsafeguard the integrity of the telecom ecosystem‚Äù. Under the new framework, all Telecommunication Identifier User Entities (TIUEs) have been given 90 days to ensure their applications function only when an active SIM card is present in the device.The order also directs telecom operators to automatically log users out of platforms such as WhatsApp, Telegram and Signal if no active SIM is detected. Messaging and social media platforms, including Snapchat, Sharechat and Jiochat, have been asked to submit compliance reports to the DoT.‚ÄúThis feature of using apps without a SIM is posing a challenge to telecom cyber security as it is being misused from outside the country to commit cyber frauds and terror activities,‚Äù the DoT had said while explaining the rationale behind the move.The directive is being fast-tracked in the Jammu and Kashmir telecom circle. While officials acknowledge that deactivating all expired or fraudulent SIMs will take time, the move is being viewed as a significant blow to the digital infrastructure used by terror networks to radicalise and manage ‚Äúwhite-collar‚Äù operatives.Failure to comply with the new norms will attract stringent action under the Telecom Cyber Security Rules and other applicable laws, officials said.The ‚Äúwhite-collar‚Äù terror module began to unravel on the intervening night of October 18-19, 2025, when posters of the banned Jaish-e-Mohammad (JeM) appeared on walls outside Srinagar city, warning of attacks on police and security forces in the Valley.Treating the development as a serious threat, Senior Superintendent of Police, Srinagar, GV Sundeep Chakravarthy constituted multiple teams to carry out an in-depth investigation. Based on the statements of the arrested accused, the probe led police to Al Falah University in Haryana‚Äôs Faridabad, where two doctors, Ganaie, a resident of Koil in south Kashmir‚Äôs Pulwama, and Shaheen Sayeed from Lucknow, were arrested.A large cache of arms and ammunition, including 2,900 kg of ammonium nitrate, potassium nitrate and sulphur, was seized during the operation, officials said.The car explosion near the Red Fort, which claimed 15 lives, is being investigated by the National Investigation Agency (NIA).
Article Summary: Officials said the probe uncovered a tactical "dual-phone" protocol followed by the module. Each accused carried two to three mobile phones. One "clean" handset was used for routine personal and professional communication. The second, described as a ‚Äúterror phone‚Äù was used exclusively for encrypted communication.

Article Title: Matthew Mercer steps back from Critical Role livestream as the creator reflects on burnout and long-term creative health
Article Text:

Popular gaming voice actor Matthew Mercer has long been the face and guiding voice behind Critical Role‚Äôs iconic ‚ÄúDungeons and Dragons‚Äù livestream. However, his decision to step away from overseeing the flagship livestream shocked many fans. He also plays a key role at Darrington Press, the studio‚Äôs game publishing arm, which launched ‚ÄúDaggerheart,‚Äù a tabletop game designed as a fresh alternative to traditional ‚ÄúDungeons and Dragons.Mercer believes that stepping away will only increase his creativity and make time for other things he wants to do. Article Title: Ten tech trends to watch in 2026
Article Text:
After years of AI hype, 2026 brings a reality check. Companies need to prove their billion-dollar bets are worth it. Data centres are spreading globally, straining power grids. AI agents are moving from pilots to production. Robots are getting smarter. New hardware forms are arriving. Meanwhile, tech billionaires keep getting richer. The gap between hype and deployment is shrinking fast, and 2026 could turn out to be a real pivoting year.

AI shifts from hype to payback

Data centres spread across the globe

Work gets reimagined

Hardware gets weird new forms

Computing gets smarter, not just bigger

New models go beyond text

Robots become real(er)

The startup birth rate soars

Tech billionaires get even richer

What the 2026 really looks like





After years of AI hype and billion-dollar bets, 2026 is shaping up to be a reality check for the tech industry. Companies that dumped money into generative AI tools now face a simple question: show us the value, or shut it down.The pace of change isn't slowing. If anything, it's getting faster. Tools that seemed cutting-edge six months ago already feel outdated. Companies are racing to stay ahead, while also trying to prove their investments weren't wasted.Here are the ten trends in technology to watch out for in 2026.The experimental phase is over. Enterprises spent 2024 and 2025 testing AI pilots and proof-of-concept projects. Now they want measurable returns on those investments."2026 is the 'show me the money' year for AI," says Venky Ganesan, a partner at Menlo Ventures. Companies will demand hard ROI numbers. Those that can't deliver value will see their software renewals drop and their fundraising dry up.This pressure will split the market. Some AI companies will thrive by solving specific problems well. Others will struggle or fail entirely. Ganesan predicts at least one major AI company will face severe financial trouble or bankruptcy in 2026.The flip side: successful companies could go public. Both OpenAI and SpaceX are eyeing IPOs at valuations near $1 trillion. If these launches succeed, they'll create a wave of new wealth and validate AI's business potential.You heard a lot about data centres in 2025. Get ready to hear more in 2026.The infrastructure boom that started in the US and China is going global. India is attracting massive investment from tech giants. Microsoft committed $17.5 billion to new data centres there. Before Microsoft's CEO left the stage at that announcement, Amazon declared it would spend $35 billion on its own facilities. Google and Meta quickly followed with their own multi-billion dollar plans.Southeast Asia is seeing double-digit growth in data centre capacity. Brazil wants to become Latin America's hub. Saudi Arabia and the UAE struck $600 billion in AI deals with the US, including plans for the largest AI campus outside America.This expansion creates real problems. These facilities consume enormous amounts of electricity and water. In hot regions, cooling requirements push consumption even higher. Brazil has already seen blackouts tied to data centre demand. Local communities often can't find out how much power and water a facility will use, thanks to legal secrecy.China offers a warning: just because you build it doesn't mean they'll come. The country rushed to construct about 150 new data centres in 2024. Now up to 80% of that new computing capacity sits unused, struggling to find customers.AI hasn't replaced most workers yet. Even though it has impacted a big number of workers, changing how work gets done in particular niches.Coding looks completely different than it did five years ago. Developers use AI assistants that can generate, debug, and refactor code. The technology has matured enough that these tools genuinely save time. Customer service is being handed over to chatbots, despite customer frustration.AI agents were the buzzword of 2025, but most stayed in pilot programs. Only 11% of organisations actually deployed them in production, despite 38% running tests. The gap between pilot and production tells the real story. Many companies automated broken processes instead of redesigning their operations from scratch. That approach rarely works.In 2026, agents will become more capable and trustworthy. They'll handle complex, multi-step tasks without constant human oversight. Think booking entire trips, negotiating better service rates, or managing workflows across different systems. "A year from now, answering questions will be the least useful thing AI can do," says Fidji Simo, OpenAI's CEO of applications. "We'll have proactive AI assistants constantly running in the background, getting things done for us. "But there's a catch. Many companies will spin out hundreds of agents per employee, only to see most sit idle. Without proper integration into existing workflows, these agents become expensive shelfware. The winners will be companies that connect agents to deterministic systems and give them clear, focused tasks.The smartphone has looked basically the same for a decade: a big black screen with some buttons on the side. That's changing.Apple is rumoured to release a folding phone in 2026. Android devices have already gone this route, even including some phones that fold twice. But Apple's loyal customer base could make folding screens mainstream.Then, a lot of others are also racing to build the first successful AI hardware device. OpenAI invested $6.5 billion in Jony Ive's startup, which is working on a physical AI product. The Humane pin and Friend necklace both made noise but never caught on. Humane has already shut down.Smart glasses present the most promising direction. They're already popular, and Meta dominates the space. In 2026, expect these devices to get smarter and more common. They offer a natural way to interact with AI without pulling out your phone.You'll also see AI show up in places you didn't ask for it. Samsung already added its Bixby assistant to refrigerators back in 2024. Hotels might offer smart duvets. Your rental car might have an AI assistant. Not all of this will be useful or wanted.The AI infrastructure race is shifting from raw scale to efficiency. You can't keep throwing more computing power at every problem."2026 will be the year of frontier versus efficient model classes," says Kaoutar El Maghraoui, a principal research scientist at IBM. Next to huge models with billions of parameters, you'll see efficient, hardware-aware models running on modest accelerators.The hardware race won't only be about GPUs anymore. ASICs, chiplet designs, analogue inference, and quantum-assisted optimisers will all mature. A new class of chips designed specifically for running AI agents could emerge.Think of it like air traffic control for AI workloads. Computing power will be packed more densely and routed dynamically. If one job slows, another moves in instantly. Nothing sits idle. This makes infrastructure smarter, more sustainable, and more adaptable.Quantum computing is also reaching an inflection point. Microsoft, Google, and others believe quantum machines will start tackling problems that classical computers can't handle. Hybrid systems that combine quantum, AI, and supercomputers could drive breakthroughs in materials science, drug development, and climate modelling.Large language models dominated AI development for the past few years. They predict the next word in a sequence. In 2026, a different approach could take centre stage: world models.World models work by learning from videos, simulations, and spatial inputs. Instead of predicting the next word, they predict what happens next in the physical world. They model how things move over time.This matters for robotics, video games, and any application where AI needs to understand cause and effect without being explicitly programmed. World models can grasp concepts like gravity or momentum just by watching.Google, Meta, and Chinese companies like Tencent are all developing world models. Yann LeCun, one of AI's pioneers, left Meta to launch a world model startup. Fei-Fei Li's company World Labs released its first model in 2025.At the same time, Europe is moving in a different direction: small language models. These are lightweight versions of LLMs designed to run on smartphones or low-powered computers. They use fewer parameters and consume less energy, but they can still handle text generation, translation, and question-answering.Small models make economic sense amid talk of the AI bubble bursting. They cost less to build, less to run, and don't require massive data centres. European governments are increasingly wary of depending on American AI infrastructure, which could accelerate investment in smaller, more sustainable models.AI security becomes mission-criticalAI creates a cybersecurity paradox: the same capabilities driving business innovation are also introducing new risks. In 2026, organisations will face mounting pressure to secure AI systems while defending against AI-powered attacks.The threats are multiplying fast. Shadow AI deployments bypass security controls. Adversarial attacks manipulate models into producing wrong outputs. AI agents operating with broad system access create new attack surfaces. "Every agent should have similar security protections as humans," says Vasu Jakkal, corporate vice president of Microsoft Security.Even OpenAI is sounding the alarm. CEO Sam Altman recently acknowledged that AI models are "starting to present some real challenges," including models that are "so good at computer security they are beginning to find critical vulnerabilities." The company is actively hiring a new Head of Preparedness to study emerging AI-related risks, from cybersecurity threats to mental health impacts. The role comes with a $555,000 salary, reflecting how seriously the company takes these challenges.Companies will need to secure four domains: data, models, applications, and infrastructure. Defenders are fighting back with AI agents for red teaming, adversarial training, and automated threat detection at machine speed.Robots are nothing like what they used to be. From pre-programmed machines, they are evolving into adaptive systems capable of perception, learning, and autonomous operation. Physical AI is breaking out of warehouses and into mainstream use.Amazon has already deployed its millionth robot, and if the company is to be believed, AI coordinates entire fleets, and that‚Äôs helping them save travel time by about 10%. At BMW plants, cars now drive themselves along production routes. The real magic, however, is when world models combine with robotics, allowing systems to comprehend their surroundings and adapt to surprises.The next frontier is humanoid robots that can navigate spaces designed for humans, as companies race to craft machines capable of doing just that. The potential stretches across manufacturing, healthcare, and disaster response, and is increasingly accessible beyond the early adopters as costs fall.AI coding tools are making it easier than ever to build software. The result: a wave of new startups hitting the market in 2026.Tools like Replit, Cursor, and Loveable let people build products without engineering backgrounds. You can go from idea to working software faster than ever before. Building AI agents is also getting simpler. Business users can create them without touching code.Not every startup will make it. Markets will get crowded. Competition will heat up. But the sheer number of new companies will reshape the landscape and push established players to move faster.Tech's wealthiest executives are about to get a lot wealthier. Ten top earners added $550 billion to their fortunes in 2025. The trend isn't slowing down.Two massive IPOs are coming: OpenAI and SpaceX, both valued near $1 trillion. SpaceX's debut will add tens of billions to Elon Musk's net worth, which already sits around $600 billion. He's also eligible for two Tesla pay packages worth a combined $1.056 trillion. Sam Altman stands to benefit from OpenAI's listing, along with major backers like Microsoft. Jeff Bezos Mark Zuckerberg , and Satya Nadella have all seen their wealth climb as AI investments pay off.Larry Ellison might be the exception. Oracle's stock dropped hard as investors questioned AI spending, erasing $80 billion in market value.Every trend in tech seems to point in one direction: more wealth flowing upward. The AI boom, the data centre buildout, the chip shortage, the agent revolution‚Äîall of it concentrates power and money in fewer hands. A handful of tech executives now wield enormous influence over technology that affects everyone's daily life.Every trend here points to the same reality: the distance between hype and deployment is collapsing. Tech used to take years to move from labs to living rooms. Now it takes months, sometimes weeks.This creates winners and losers fast. Companies that can't prove AI's value will fold. Workers in certain fields will find their jobs radically different or gone entirely. Cities welcoming data centres might face power shortages they didn't plan for. Meanwhile, a small group of tech billionaires keeps getting richer off all of it, concentrating more control over systems that affect billions of people.The pace isn't slowing down. If anything, 2026 will be the year when that becomes impossible to ignore.
Article Summary: After years of AI hype, 2026 brings a reality check. Companies need to prove their billion-dollar bets are worth it. Data centres are spreading globally, straining power grids. AI agents are moving from pilots to production. Robots are getting smarter. New hardware forms are arriving.

Article Text:
As job cuts continue to rise in various industries, some employees are going for 'career cushioning'.

Q: What is career cushioning?

Q: Why is career cushioning important?

NEW DELHI: Microsoft Corp is reportedly planning to cut thousands of jobs, with some roles expected to be eliminated in the human resources and engineering divisions, according to media reports on Tuesday.This move follows similar job cuts announced by other tech companies, such as Amazon, Meta Platforms , Twitter, Google , Salesforce and a host of other corporations.These job cuts are being attributed to slowing demand and a worsening global economic outlook. The move by Microsoft indicates that the tech sector may continue to shed jobs in the coming months.As job cuts continue to rise in tech and various other industries, some employees are choosing to proactively seek out new job opportunities while still employed. This strategy, referred to as " career cushioning ". Here is all you need to know on 'career cushioning'A: Career cushioning refers to the practice of building a diverse set of skills and experiences in order to make oneself more marketable and resilient to job loss or industry changes. This can include gaining experience in multiple areas of a field, developing a side hustle or passion project, or building a professional network.A: Career cushioning can help provide a sense of security and confidence in uncertain job markets and can also open up new opportunities for career advancement. It can also help you be better prepared if you do lose your job, making it easier to find new employment.A: There are several ways to begin career cushioning, such as:Building a diverse skill set through continuing education or volunteer workNetworking with professionals in your industry and other industriesBuilding a personal brand through social media and professional online presenceSaving money for unexpected career changes or job loss.A: Some examples of career cushioning include:-A software developer taking on freelance web design projects to gain experience in user interface design.-A marketing professional starting a blog to gain experience in content creation.-A sales representative taking on additional responsibilities in product development to gain experience in product management.A: No, career cushioning is applicable for people in any industry. It's about being proactive in preparing for potential changes in your career, regardless of the industry you're in.A: It's a good idea to review your career cushioning efforts regularly, perhaps once or twice a year. This will allow you to assess your progress and make any necessary adjustments to your plans. Additionally, keeping an eye on the job market and industry trends can help you anticipate and prepare for any potential changes in your field.A: You can gauge the effectiveness of your career cushioning efforts by monitoring your progress in gaining new skills and experiences, as well as the feedback you receive from your professional network and potential employers. Additionally, you may find that you are better able to adapt to changes in your industry, or that you have more opportunities available to you.A: The amount of time you should dedicate to career cushioning will depend on your individual goals and circumstances, however it's important to balance the time you spend career cushioning with your other responsibilities. A good rule of thumb is to spend some time each week or month working on career cushioning activities, but not to the point that it negatively impacts other areas of your life.

Article Title: Did Starmer impose a curfew in the UK? No, it's just a fake TikTok video
Article Text:
Keir Starmer

Coup In Britain? Starmer‚Äôs ‚ÄòOwn Cabinet Plots‚Äô His Downfall | ‚ÄòFull Bunker Mode‚Äô In No. 10





The 61-second video of UK PM Keir Starmer would be shocking, if it were true. "The UK is set to introduce a nationwide curfew, beginning at 11pm each night," he appears to say on one of thousands of TikTok videos of him posted in last six months. "Under the new rule, no one will be permitted to leave their home after 11pm without official authorisation."Starmer never made any such policy or announcement. But thanks to AI, the PM in the short video sounded eerily like the real one. The fake video attracted over 430,000 views and inspired similar posts on X and Facebook. That video, and other similar ones, appears to have been taken down by the Chinese-owned social media company, which officially prohibits "fake authoritative sources or crisis events, or falsely shows public figures in certain contexts. "But the clip was just one of 6,042 such videos, most featuring Starmer, identified by NewsGuard, a company that tracks online misinformation, between May and Dec. In a report, it said the videos were posted by accounts with names of fake, British-sounding news organisations like "BBB UK News" and "Daily Britain News." Together, the accounts had more than 1 million followers when the report was issued. "It consistently emulates Starmer," said Eva Maitland, senior analyst for Russian influence at NewsGuard."It produces false or baseless claims that look bad for the Starmer govt, and they're kind of created to create a strong response from people so that they'll click on it."Maitland said the videos do not appear to be part of a coordinated effort by foreign adversaries like Russia or the PM's domestic political opponents to damage him in the eyes of voters. Rather, she said, they are likely being created by content producers whose primary goal is to make money by making videos that go viral.The widespread adoption of easy-to-use AI video generation tools, like OpenAI's Sora, has dramatically increased the number of fake videos on TikTok and other social media platforms. The fake videos come at a particularly difficult time for the PM, who is already suffering from very low polling numbers. In one video, Starmer seems to announce new drivers licence laws that could strip many British people of their ability to drive legally in the country. Another video has Starmer's faked voice declaring that new rules will allow the authorities to access any British person's phone, along with its private data.In the immediate days after NewsGuard published its report on Dec 9, many of the videos were available on TikTok. By Dec 19, most appeared to have been removed from the platform. Howard said the use of AI in politics is increasing rapidly. "We know it's internationally pervasive now," he said. "Four of every five elections around the world now have AI-generated political junk that is unattributed and clearly misleading. "
Article Summary: Thousands of fake videos of UK PM Keir Starmer have been posted on TikTok. The videos were created by accounts with fake, British-sounding news organisations. NewsGuard, a company that tracks online misinformation, identified 6,042 such videos between May and Dec.

Article Title: How Burj Khalifa still defies wind, heat, gravity in 2026: Engineering secrets of world‚Äôs tallest building revealed
Article Text:
Burj Khalifa Was Never Meant to Be This Tall: Design Trick That Lets Dubai‚Äôs Skyscraper ‚ÄòConfuse the Wind‚Äô and Stay Rock Solid

Burj Khalifa as a vision of height and how it grew taller



Burj Khalifa‚Äôs breakthrough: Buttressed core system



Burj Khalifa‚Äôs engineering against the elements: Wind, heat, sand



Burj Khalifa‚Äôs safety, sustainability and built in innovation



Burj Khalifa: A legacy that is larger than its height







When the Burj Khalifa opened on January 4, 2010, it did not just take the title of the world‚Äôs tallest building, it announced Dubai to the world as a hub of ambition, innovation and architectural daring. More than a decade later, architects and engineers still marvel at how it was done and how the structure continues to stand as a benchmark of engineering excellence. At the centre of that success is Bill Baker, the structural engineer whose pioneering designs made the 828-metre landmark possible.Read on as we explore the groundbreaking systems and safety features that not only helped build Burj Khalifa but keep it safe, stable and relevant in 2026, by design as much as by physics.Did you know that the original concept for the Burj Khalifa was not always as tall as it is today? The building began life planned for about 518 metres but as engineers tested and refined the design, they realised it was possible to go much higher while keeping stability and cost efficiency in check. Through iterative wind-tunnel experiments and modelling, the team increased the design by another 310 metres, roughly the height of the Eiffel Tower, without compromising safety or performance.This refinement was not just ambition, it was engineering evolution. From the outset, the project‚Äôs core team, led by Emaar Properties and coordinated with global experts, approached the build with flexibility and scientific rigour. The result is not just a taller building but a smarter one.At the heart of Burj Khalifa‚Äôs structural resilience is an innovative design known as the ‚Äúbuttressed core‚Äù, a concept developed by Baker and his colleagues at Skidmore, Owings & Merrill (SOM). This system uses a central reinforced core shaped like an irregular hexagon, with three wings extending outward in a Y-shaped plan.For its torsional stability, the hexagonal core acts much like an axle, resisting twists and turns that wind forces cause at great heights. For wind resistance, each wing buttresses the others, distributing load evenly and making the structure incredibly stable even in strong gusts. Burj Khalifa's aerodynamic efficiency is credited to the unusual shape that helps ‚Äúconfuse the wind‚Äù, so vortices don‚Äôt form consistently around the surface, dramatically reducing oscillation forces.This structural system made it possible for Burj Khalifa to break previous height records by a huge margin, not incrementally but dramatically. It is a standard-setter that has since influenced other super-tall buildings around the world.Dubai‚Äôs environmental conditions presented unique challenges. With summer temperatures often exceeding 50 ¬∞C and desert winds exerting unpredictable force, the design team needed solutions on multiple fronts. For the wind tunnel testing, the team conducted over 40 wind tunnel analyses to model how the building would respond to every possible force, adjusting setbacks and facade angles accordingly.For concrete and cladding, special cladding panels (about 26,000 of them) were hand-cut to fit perfectly and minimise thermal and light stress. Ultra-reflective materials protect the structure from heat gain. For its foundations, instead of sitting directly on loose sand, Burj Khalifa rises from a reinforced concrete mat supported by deep bored piles, anchoring the entire 828-metre tower on solid ground.Beyond these classical engineering feats, modern protective technologies like cathodic corrosion protection help guard steel reinforcement in the foundation from salt-rich groundwater, ensuring a long lifespan for the structure at its base.The Burj Khalifa was designed long before ‚Äúsustainability‚Äù became a global buzzword, yet some of its features anticipated today‚Äôs priorities. Its efficient skin design is such that because of its Y-plan, only one-sixth of the building‚Äôs surface is exposed to direct sunlight at any time, which reduces solar heat gain and improves cooling efficiency.For fresh water harvesting, instead of letting condensate from air-conditioning systems drain away, the building‚Äôs design captures the equivalent of 20 Olympic-size pools of water each year, which is a hidden but smart reuse strategy. For Baker and the original design team, the real reward is not just in the height record or technical achievements, it is in seeing how the building continues to stand tall, safe and relevant more than a decade after its completion.Looking ahead, experts say that Burj Khalifa‚Äôs core concepts will continue to influence future tall-building design, even as materials and technologies evolve. Baker has hinted that even taller structures, potentially breaching the kilometre mark, are possible, though they would likely require new structural systems and solutions for challenges like vertical transportation and pressure changes at extreme heights.In the meantime, Burj Khalifa remains a testament to the blend of human ambition, scientific rigour and architectural artistry. It is a building that did not just redefine Dubai but reshaped what the world believes is possible in vertical architecture.

Article Title: UAE Bank to end SMS OTPs for online transactions from Jan 6, switch to biometric authentication
Article Text:
UAE‚Äôs big banking change for online card transactions / AI Generated Image

Why are UAE banks ending SMS OTPs?

SIM-Swapping: Criminals trick mobile providers into porting your number to their SIM card, effectively "stealing" your identity and receiving your OTPs directly.

Phishing Scams: Fraudsters create fake websites that look exactly like your bank or a delivery service, tricking you into typing your OTP into their hands.

Interception: Advanced hackers can sometimes intercept SMS messages as they travel through the air using outdated "SS7" protocols.

What are in-app approvals?



The Trigger: You click "Pay" on a shopping website or app.

The Notification: Instead of an SMS, you‚Äôll receive a push notification directly from your bank‚Äôs official mobile app.

The Review: When you tap the notification, the app opens to show you the exact merchant name and the amount being charged‚Äîno more "blindly" entering codes.

The Approval: You confirm the transaction using biometric verification (Face ID or fingerprint) or your secure Smart Pass PIN.

What does the resident need to do now?

Update your bank‚Äôs mobile app to the latest version.

Enable push notifications and biometric login in the app settings.

Log in to your account and complete any authentication setup before January 6.

Why should you act now?





If you‚Äôve lived in the UAE for a while, the "ping" of an incoming SMS with a six-digit code has been the soundtrack to your online shopping. But that sound is about to become a relic of the past. Starting January 6, 2026, several major UAE banks will officially stop sending One-Time Passwords (OTPs) via text message for online card payments.This isn't just a minor update; it‚Äôs a full-scale security revolution mandated by the Central Bank of the UAE (CBUAE). For years, SMS codes were the gold standard for two-factor authentication, but as hackers became more sophisticated, the "weak links" in the SMS system became too big to ignore.By shifting to a mobile-first approach, the UAE is positioning itself as a global leader in protecting its residents' hard-earned money.The primary reason for this change is simple: Security. While SMS is convenient, it travels over open telecommunications networks that were never designed for high-stakes banking.This made them prime targets for three specific types of fraud:According to industry reports, SMS-related fraud caused billions in global losses.In the UAE alone, scams saw a significant jump in recent years, prompting the Central Bank to issue Notice 2025/3057, which effectively bans SMS and email OTPs as a standalone security method.The future of banking in the UAE is "In-App Authentication." Instead of waiting for a text and manually typing in a code, the process is now much faster and more integrated. Here is what your next online purchase will look like:This "closed-loop" system ensures that the person approving the transaction is physically holding the trusted device. It removes the need for the telephone network entirely, which is also a massive win for travelers who often struggle to receive SMS codes while roaming.This isn‚Äôt just a technical update, it affects every resident who shops online or uses digital banking in the UAE.How to prepare:Once SMS OTPs are phased out, you won‚Äôt be able to approve online card purchases using text codes. Transactions will be declined unless verified through the bank app. This change also means that iPhone or Android users must ensure their device settings allow notifications from their bank app.If you haven‚Äôt already switched to app-based authentication, banks generally recommend doing so well before the deadline to avoid disruptions.This step is part of a larger plan led by the Central Bank of the UAE to strengthen digital banking infrastructure. Regulators have mandated that banks phase out SMS and email OTPs by March 2026 at the latest, although many instituted the change early.The goal is to reduce fraud and align with global best practices, as digital fraud patterns evolve. By moving to in-app authentication with biometric verification and encrypted channels, banks aim to create a more secure, convenient and unified payment experience for customers.
Article Summary: Starting January 6, 2026, several major UAE banks will officially stop sending One-Time Passwords via text message for online card payments. Instead of an SMS, you‚Äôll receive a push notification directly from your bank‚Äôs official mobile app. Transactions will be declined unless verified through the bank app.

Article Title: Ask Dhirendra: 'How do I decide how much to save and invest when my income is just about enough?'
Article Text:
The problem is not which fund to choose. It‚Äôs how much they can realistically save. (AI image)

‚ÄúHow do I decide how much to save and invest when my income is just about enough?‚Äù

What can you save today without breaking your life? How can you make that number grow every year?

Where does a typical salary go?

Some expenses are non-negotiable (rent, basic food, fees).

Some are negotiable but important (a modest phone, occasional eating out).

Some are pure leakage (unused subscriptions, impulsive orders, ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt even remember what this was‚Äù).

From spare change to serious money

Step up your SIP before you step up your lifestyle

First, add up your genuine essentials: rent/EMI, groceries, utilities, fees, basic transport.

Next, be realistic and add a modest amount for discretionary spending that you know you‚Äôll do anyway ‚Äì because you are human, not a robot.

See what is left. From that leftover, commit to a percentage ‚Äì even 10% of your take-home income ‚Äì as a non-negotiable saving and investing amount. Set up automatic transfers and SIPs for that right after your salary date.

If you have any queries for Dhirendra Kumar you can drop us an email at: toi.business@timesinternet.in

(Dhirendra Kumar is Founder and CEO of Value Research)

This is one of those questions that sounds technical, but is actually very emotional.On paper, it‚Äôs simple: income comes in, expenses go out, and whatever is left is ‚Äúsavings. In real life, income comes in, rent, EMIs, school fees, petrol, Swiggy, Zomato, sale on Myntra, birthday gifts, one sudden expense‚Ä¶ and at the end of the month, you look at your balance and say, ‚ÄúI‚Äôll start investing from next month. Pakka.‚ÄùNext month looks surprisingly similar.So let‚Äôs start with an honest admission: for most people, the problem is not which fund to choose. It‚Äôs how much they can realistically save when it feels like the money is just about enough.At Value Research, whenever we look at this, we don‚Äôt begin with a number like ‚Äúyou must save 30%‚Äù. We start with a different idea: savings are not what is left after spending. Savings are what you decide first; spending adjusts after that if you flip this order, the maths ‚Äì and your behaviour ‚Äì changes completely.A good rule of thumb for many middle-class households is to allocate 20‚Äì30% of their take-home income to savings and investments. However, I also know that for many people today, 30% sounds like a bad joke. So instead of fighting over the ‚Äúideal‚Äù number, let‚Äôs work with two simpler questions:To answer the first question, you need to know where your money is actually going, not where you think it is going.For one or two months, track your expenses honestly ‚Äì not for Instagram, for yourself. You don‚Äôt need an app; even a simple notebook or spreadsheet works.Once you see your own pie chart, three things usually stand out:Your first ‚Äúinvestment‚Äù might simply be plugging two or three leaks. Even if that frees up only ‚Çπ2,000‚Äì‚Çπ3,000 a month, that is your starting SIP.Now let‚Äôs look at how ‚Äúsmall‚Äù that really is.When we run these numbers at Value Research in our retirement and goal calculators, the results are always the same: the gap between zero and small is far bigger than the gap between small and perfect.But what if your income truly is at the survival stage? There are people for whom even ‚Çπ2,000 is a luxury some months. If that‚Äôs your reality, you have two parallel jobs. One is to create a tiny habit ‚Äì even ‚Çπ500 or ‚Çπ1,000 a month into a recurring deposit or a conservative fund. The absolute amount is less important than the mental switch from ‚ÄúI‚Äôll save if anything is left‚Äù to ‚ÄúI will save something, and then I will live on the rest. ‚ÄùThe second job is to make sure that as your income grows, your lifestyle doesn‚Äôt expand at the same speed. This is where a lot of middle-class Indians quietly sabotage themselves. Every salary increase automatically becomes a better phone, nicer meals out, upgraded gadgets, and bigger car loans. The percentage saved stays the same, or sometimes even falls.A very powerful habit ‚Äì one we often build into plans at Value Research ‚Äì is the ‚Äústep-up‚Äù. Each year, when your salary goes up, you increase your SIPs and savings before you upgrade anything else.In many examples we‚Äôve run, the step-up strategy leads to a dramatically higher corpus at the end, without you ever feeling an acute ‚Äúsacrifice‚Äù in any single year. You just avoid letting every pay hike leak out into lifestyle.Now, how do you decide your own number?Here‚Äôs a simple approach:If that number feels tight, start a little lower and promise yourself one thing: every time your income goes up, your savings rate will go up faster than your spending.At Value Research, when we build long-term plans, we don‚Äôt assume people will suddenly start saving 40% from next month. We assume they will start somewhere realistic, and then we design step-ups. The rigour is in the process, not in some magical starting number.One last point. Many people postpone investing because they are embarrassed by how small their starting amount looks. Please don‚Äôt underestimate the psychological power of seeing a small, growing pile that you started and maintained. It changes how you think about yourself: from ‚ÄúI can‚Äôt save‚Äù to ‚ÄúI am someone who always saves something.‚Äù That identity is worth more than one extra dinner out.So how much should you save and invest when your income feels just about enough? The honest answer is: start with whatever you can without lying to yourself, protect that amount like you protect your rent, and then make sure it rises every time your income increases. The ‚Äúright‚Äù number is not what a formula says; it‚Äôs the number you will actually stick to for the next 20 years.The perfect percentage can wait. The first rupee cannot.
Article Summary: Dhirendra Kumar: For most people, the problem is not which fund to choose. It‚Äôs how much they can realistically save when it feels like the money is just about enough. A good rule of thumb for many middle-class households is to allocate 20‚Äì30% of their take-home income.

Article Title: Nominee vs legal heir: What is the difference and who has claim on assets? All you need to know
Article Text:
AI image

Who is a Nominee?



Who is a Legal Heir?

Difference between a Nominee and a Legal heir

Aspect Nominee Legal Heir Role Custodian Owner Transfer of Assets Can be done without any legal formalities. Requires testamentary documents for proof of ownership. Powers No power to transact, use, or transfer assets. Power to use and transact assets as an owner. Appointment Owner can appoint anyone, but some institutions specify certain conditions. Determined by succession/personal laws. Legal Right Cannot contest ownership legally. Can contest ownership in a court of law.

When individuals open bank accounts, invest in mutual funds, or buy insurance, they are often asked to name a nominee.However, many people mistakenly assume that the nominee automatically inherits the assets. In reality, the nominee is not always the final recipient ‚Äî the ownership rights belong to the legal heir, reported ET.Understanding the distinction between these two is essential to ensure that your wealth is passed on to the intended beneficiaries.A nominee acts as a temporary custodian of the deceased person‚Äôs assets.The nominee‚Äôs role is limited to holding and managing the assets until they are legally transferred to the rightful heirs.According to ET, the nominee cannot sell, trade, or make any transactional decisions about the assets.The account or policy owner can appoint anyone ‚Äî family, friends, or acquaintances ‚Äî as a nominee, though financial institutions often prefer close family members.In some cases, the nominee and the legal heir can be the same person, which helps in ensuring a smoother transfer of assets.The legal heir or beneficiary is the rightful owner of the assets once the original holder passes away.To claim ownership, the legal heir must produce valid documents such as a will or other testamentary proof.If there is no will ‚Äî a situation known as dying intestate ‚Äî the heir is determined as per the country‚Äôs succession or personal laws, reported ET.While a nominee can initially access the assets, only the legal heir can claim them permanently or challenge ownership in court.Experts quoted by ET emphasise that having clarity on this difference helps avoid disputes and ensures that the savings reach the intended family members or beneficiaries.Therefore, it is advisable to regularly update both nominees and wills to align with one‚Äôs estate planning goals.
Article Summary: A nominee acts as a temporary custodian of the deceased person‚Äôs assets. The legal heir or beneficiary is the rightful owner of the assets once the original holder passes away. To claim ownership, the legal heir must produce valid documents such as a will.

How Jeevan Pramaan simplifies pensioner verification



Every year, lakhs of pensioners across India must prove that they are still alive to continue receiving their pension. This verification, known as the Life Certificate or Digital Life Certificate (DLC), is a crucial and mandatory step in ensuring that pension payments are made only to eligible recipients, preventing fraud and misuse.Traditionally, this process involved visiting the bank or pension office in person, standing in long queues, and submitting a signed paper certificate. However, with the government‚Äôs focus on digitisation and technological advancement, this process has become much simpler, faster, and more convenient. Pensioners can now submit their certificates digitally from the comfort of their homes using Jeevan Pramaan, a secure, user-friendly, and Aadhaar-based platform.A Life Certificate is an official document that confirms a pensioner is alive. Without it, pension payments are automatically paused by the pension disbursing agency. This verification is essential for preventing fraudulent claims and ensuring that pensions reach the rightful beneficiaries.The Digital Life Certificate (DLC), also known as Jeevan Pramaan, is an advanced biometric-enabled version of the traditional paper certificate.Introduced by the Government of India, it uses Aadhaar-based biometric authentication using either fingerprint or iris scan to verify a pensioner‚Äôs identity. Once verified, a digital certificate is automatically generated and shared with authorised pension disbursing agencies.This online process eliminates the need for physical verification, providing elderly pensioners with a simpler and more accessible way to maintain their pension benefits.According to PIB, The submission of the Life Certificate is mandatory for all pensioners who wish to continue receiving their pension without interruption. For the year 2025, the standard submission period is betweenTo make the process more comfortable for the elderly, the government allows pensioners aged 80 years and above to begin the submission process earlier, from 1 October 2025. This extended window gives senior citizens more time and flexibility to complete the procedure without facing last-minute difficulties.The Jeevan Pramaan process involves two main steps: registering the biometric device and generating the digital certificate.Before using the service, pensioners or operators must register their biometric device such as a fingerprint or iris scanner. During registration, the user provides their Aadhaar number and mobile number, after which an OTP (One-Time Password) is sent to their mobile. After entering the OTP, they must provide their name and email ID before scanning their fingerprint or iris.Once authentication is complete, the system confirms that device registration was successful, allowing the user to move to the next step.In this step, the pensioner enters personal details such as Aadhaar number, mobile number, name, PPO number, pension type, sanctioning authority, disbursing agency, and bank account details. The system also asks whether the pensioner has remarried or is re-employed.After entering all details, the pensioner scans their fingerprint or iris using the registered biometric device. Upon successful authentication, the Digital Life Certificate is generated, and an SMS acknowledgment with the Jeevan Pramaan Certificate ID is sent to the registered mobile number.This certificate is automatically stored in the Life Certificate Repository, accessible anytime to both pensioners and pension agencies.Once the Digital Life Certificate is created, it can be electronically delivered to the concerned Pension Disbursing Agency (PDA). PDAs can log in to the Jeevan Pramaan portal to view, verify, or download the certificate directly.Pensioners can also download a PDF copy of their certificate by visiting the Jeevan Pramaan website and entering their Pramaan ID or Aadhaar number. This ensures transparency and easy access for future reference.The government provides several options to submit the Life Certificate, allowing pensioners to choose the method that suits them best.Pensioners who prefer traditional methods can visit their bank branch or a Citizen Service Centre (CSC) to submit their Life Certificate physically. Trained staff at these centres assist pensioners in verifying their details and completing the process.For those unable to travel due to age or health issues, India Post Payments Bank (IPPB) offers a doorstep banking service. Pensioners can schedule an appointment, and an IPPB representative will visit their home to complete the submission using biometric authentication. This service is available for both IPPB and non-IPPB account holders.For pensioners comfortable with technology, the Jeevan Pramaan portal provides a completely online process. By visiting https://jeevanpramaan.gov.in, pensioners can submit their Digital Life Certificate using a computer, laptop, or smartphone equipped with a fingerprint or iris scanner.The system uses the Aadhaar platform to authenticate biometric details. Key components of hallmark on gold jewellery



Gold, silver hallmarking : Gold and silver jewllery have long been treasured for their beauty and value. However, ensuring their purity and authenticity is important, especially in a market prone to fraudulent practices. This is where the hallmarking scheme comes into play. Here‚Äôs what you need to know about hallmarking charges and its procedures:Hallmarking is the process of accurately determining and officially recording the proportionate content of precious metals in articles, such as gold and silver.It serves as a guarantee of their purity or fineness. In India, hallmarking is governed by stringent standards outlined in IS 15820, according to an ET report.Hallmarking charges are applied per article, regardless of its weight. For gold articles, the charge is Rs 45 per article, with a minimum charge of Rs 200 for a consignment. Similarly, for silver articles, the charge is Rs 35 per article, with a minimum charge of Rs 150 for a consignment. It's important to note that additional taxes and levies may apply.A consignment refers to a collection of articles with the same fineness, from which a sample is drawn and assayed for compliance. Different lots may exist within a consignment.Anyone can have their hallmarked jewellery tested for purity at an A&H centre by paying a testing fee of Rs. 200 (for testing using the fire assay method as per IS 1418). These centres must be recognized by the BIS. The list of recognized A&H centres is available on the BIS website under the hallmarking section.The primary objective of hallmarking is to safeguard consumers from counterfeit products. To achieve this, the Indian government made hallmarking mandatory for gold jewellery from June 16, 2021. Since April 1, 2023, jewellers are prohibited from selling any gold jewellery without a 6-digit Hallmark Unique Identification ( HUID ) number.If you bought gold jewellery on or before June 30, 2021, it may have old hallmarking signs. These signs include the purity/fineness mark and the BIS emblem, along with two additional indications: the jeweller's identification number and the assay centre's mark/number.However, starting July 1, 2021, these two indications were replaced with a unique alphanumeric HUID code. The hallmark remains valid for the lifetime of the jewellery, and consumers can sell old jewellery, whether hallmarked or un-hallmarked, to jewellers.The HUID, or hallmark Unique Identification number, is a key component of hallmarking in gold jewellery. It's a unique six-digit alphanumeric code assigned to each hallmarked item, allowing for traceability. Customers can verify the HUID number using the 'Verify HUID' feature in the BIS Care App.Since the introduction of the HUID on July 1, 2021, the hallmark on gold jewellery consists of three marks: the BIS logo, the purity of the article in caratage and fineness, and a unique six-digit alphanumeric HUID number.
Article Summary: Hallmarking is the process of accurately determining and officially recording the proportionate content of precious metals in articles, such as gold and silver. In India, hallmarking is governed by stringent standards outlined in IS 15820. Since April 1, 2023, jewellers are prohibited from selling any gold jewellery without a 6-digit Hallmark Unique Identification number.

Article Title: Samsung plans to double Gemini-powered AI devices to 800 million in 2026, says co-CEO T M Roh
Article Text:
No company immune to memory chip shortage





Samsung Electronics co-CEO T M Roh said that the company aims to double the number of its mobile devices with AI features powered by Google's Gemini in 2026. By 2025, the South Korean firm had rolled out Gemini-backed AI features to about 400 million mobile products, including smartphones and tablets. It now plans to boost that figure to 800 million in the current year. ‚ÄúWe will apply AI to all products, all functions, and all services as quickly as possible,‚Äù Roh told news agency Reuters in his first interview since becoming the company‚Äôs co-CEO in November. With the move, Samsung seeks to reclaim its lost crown from Apple in the smartphone market, the report says. It also aims to fend off competition from Chinese rivals not only in mobile telephones, but televisions and home appliances, all overseen by Roh.Roh said that other than search, consumers o frequently use a range of generative AI editing and productivity tools for images and others, as well as translation and summary features on smartphones.As per the report, Roh expects the adoption of AI to accelerate, as Samsung's surveys on awareness of its Galaxy AI brand jumped to a level of 80% from about 30% in just one year. "Even though the AI technology might seem a bit doubtful right now, within six months to a year, these technologies will become more widespread," he said.According to the report, a global shortage of memory chips is a boon to Samsung's mainstay semiconductor business, but it may impact margins on the smartphone business, its second largest revenue source."As this situation is unprecedented, no company is immune to its impact," Roh told the agency, adding that the crisis affects not only mobile phones but other consumer electronics, from TVs to home appliances.He did not rule out raising product prices, saying some impact was "inevitable" from a surge in memory chip prices, but Samsung, the world‚Äôs No.1 TV maker, is working with partners on longer term strategies to minimise the impact.During the interaction, Roh acknowledged that the market for foldable phones has been growing slower than expected. He attributed this to the engineering complexities and lack of applications suitable for the hardware design, but expected the segment to go mainstream in the next two or three years. He said that a "very high" rate of foldable phone users opt for the same segment for their next purchase.
Article Summary: Samsung aims to double the number of its mobile devices with AI features by 2026. By 2025, the South Korean firm had rolled out Gemini-backed AI features to about 400 million mobile products, including smartphones and tablets. With the move, Samsung seeks to reclaim its lost crown from Apple in the smartphone market.
